title: 111_hr5333
content: The Act is titled the "Children of Military Service Members Commemorative Lapel Pin Act" and it involves the Department of Defense recognizing dependent children of members of the Armed Forces. The Act "Children of Military Service Members Commemorative Lapel Pin Act" amends Chapter 57 of title 10, United States Code by introducing a new section for the design and eligibility of a lapel button to recognize eligible children of military service members who serve on active duty for more than 30 days. The Secretary of Defense will approve the design and oversee the application and presentation process. The Act "Children of Military Service Members Commemorative Lapel Pin Act" amends Chapter 57 of title 10, United States Code to recognize eligible children of military service members who serve on active duty for more than 30 days. The Secretary of Defense will establish an application process for eligible child dependents to request a commemorative lapel button, which will be presented upon application processing and fee payment. Upon application processing and fee payment, the Secretary will present a children of military service members commemorative lapel button to eligible child dependents of a member. The cost of the lapel button must be covered by the payment. Each eligible child dependent is limited to receiving one lapel button, regardless of the member's active duty service frequency. The children of military service members commemorative lapel button is limited to one per eligible child dependent, regardless of the member's active duty service frequency. However, if a person is a dependent of more than one member, they may receive a lapel button for each member they are dependent on. The children of military service members commemorative lapel button can be replaced if lost or damaged without fault. An eligible child dependent is defined as a dependent of a member of the armed forces. The text discusses the definition of an eligible child dependent of a member of the armed forces and the regulations that the Secretary of Defense must issue to carry out this section. The text discusses the expedited implementation of the children of military service members commemorative lapel button authorized by section 1126a of title 10, United States Code. Congress urges the Secretary of Defense to expedite the design, manufacture, establishment, and implementation of mechanisms for issuing the lapel button. The Secretary of Defense is required to make the children of military service members commemorative lapel button available to individuals who can prove eligibility. The children of military service members lapel button is authorized by law and available to eligible individuals who can prove their status as a dependent of a member of the Armed Forces who served on active duty for more than 30 days. The Secretary of Defense will establish an application process for eligible individuals. The Secretary of Defense will provide an application process for eligible children of military service members to apply for a commemorative lapel button. Additionally, members of the Armed Forces who served on active duty for more than 30 days since September 11, 2001, will be notified of the button's availability. The Secretary of Defense will notify eligible members of the Armed Forces who served on active duty for more than 30 days since September 11, 2001, about the children of military service members commemorative lapel button. Applications for the button must be submitted to the Secretary of Defense. Applications for the children of military service members commemorative lapel button must be submitted to the Secretary of Defense within one year of the announcement of its availability. Costs, limitations, and exceptions apply as per section 1126a of title 10, United States Code. Costs, limitations, and exceptions from section 1126a of title 10, United States Code, apply to the presentation of a children of military service members commemorative lapel button.
